of employees witnessing a positive change in Microsoft\u0026#8217;s workplace culture fell from 62% in January to 40% in July. The Nasdaq Composite posted a weekly gain of 1.67%. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Fed \u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/economics/macro-economic-events/23/07/33405535/federal-reserves-no-shock-rate-hike-draws-mixed-reactions-from-economists-what-th\"\u003edecided to relaunch its rate-hike campaign\u003c/a\u003e at the latest FOMC meeting, pushing the federal funds rate to 5.25%-5.5%. The cost of borrowing is now at its highest level since 2001. Fed Chair\u003cstrong\u003e Jerome Powell\u003c/strong\u003e \u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/economics/macro-economic-events/23/07/33401716/powell-keeps-interest-rate-hikes-on-the-table-curbs-market-excitement-tech-falls-\"\u003edidn't discard the possibility of a new hike in the upcoming September FOMC meeting\u003c/a\u003e. He's worried that core inflation, at 4.8%, continues to be too high but said the Fed will base the decision on the two monthly inflation reports left before the next meeting.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMeanwhile, several macroeconomic measures are showing hope for the U.S. to skip a possible recession. A new report by the Bureau of Economic Analysis \u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/economics/macro-economic-events/23/07/33419003/us-gdp-expands-at-booming-2-4-in-q2-beating-estimates-on-heels-of-latest-fed-rate\"\u003eput economic growth at 2.4% annually in the second quarter of 2023\u003c/a\u003e, beating expectations of 1.8% growth. Consumer confidence rose to a two-year high, \u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/economics/macro-economic-events/23/07/33373087/pandemic-shadows-lift-as-us-consumer-confidence-soars-to-2-year-high\"\u003edriven by a strong job market and a steady decrease in inflation\u003c/a\u003e. The personal consumption expenditure price index, which is the Fed's favorite measure for inflation, \u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/economics/macro-economic-events/23/07/33441488/feds-favored-inflation-gauge-cools-to-2-year-lows-strong-spending-keeps-fed-rate-\"\u003ealso fell to a two-year low in June.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSome of the highest profile companies in Big Tech released earnings this week. \u003cstrong\u003eMicrosoft\u003c/strong\u003e (NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/MSFT#NASDAQ\"\u003eMSFT\u003c/a\u003e) shares fell\u003cstrong\u003e \u003c/strong\u003e2.19% on the week as investors showed disappointment from slowed growth from Azure, the company's cloud arm. A lack of quick gains from Microsoft's booming AI efforts also disappointed investors, although analysts were quick to say that\u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/analyst-ratings/analyst-color/23/07/33394837/5-analysts-size-up-microsoft-shares-after-q4-earnings-in-the-early-innings-of-a-mas\"\u003e gains from those developments will come later in the year.\u003c/a\u003e Several raised their Microsoft price targets. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGoogle's parent company \u003cstrong\u003eAlphabet\u003c/strong\u003e (NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/GOOG#NASDAQ\"\u003eGOOG\u003c/a\u003e) \u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/news/earnings/23/07/33390811/alphabet-stock-is-rising-wednesday-whats-driving-the-action\"\u003eposted a year-over-year revenue growth of 7% for the second quarter\u003c/a\u003e, beating analyst estimates and taking the company's shares up 8.9% over the week. This caused \u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/news/earnings/23/07/33389005/alphabet-analysts-raise-their-forecasts-after-upbeat-q2-earnings\"\u003eseveral analysts to raise their forecasts\u003c/a\u003e on the company. Investors also took a liking to \u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/analyst-ratings/analyst-color/23/07/33394716/alphabets-ai-integration-winning-over-5-analysts-q2-results-spark-optimism-despite-\"\u003ethe company's advancement in the AI field\u003c/a\u003e, where it had been left behind by Microsoft and partner \u003cstrong\u003eOpenAI\u003c/strong\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt's a similar story for \u003cstrong\u003eMeta\u003c/strong\u003e (NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/META#NASDAQ\"\u003eMETA\u003c/a\u003e), formerly known as Facebook. The company posted 11% year-over-year revenue growth for the second quarter and beat earnings estimates, taking the stock higher by more than 10% on the week. AI investments were also central to the company's competitive strategy, \u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/analyst-ratings/analyst-color/23/07/33420600/5-analysts-mixed-on-meta-platforms-post-q2-valuation-boost-ai-growth-but-concerns-o\"\u003ecausing several investors to raise their price predictions\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIntel\u003c/strong\u003e (NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/INTC#NASDAQ\"\u003eINTC\u003c/a\u003e) CEO \u003cstrong\u003ePat Gelsinger\u003c/strong\u003e said on the second-quarter earnings call the chipmaker is \"well-positioned to capitalize on the significant growth\" of AI, although \u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/news/earnings/23/07/33430319/intel-rallies-on-q2-earnings-beat-ceo-says-chipmaker-well-positioned-in-ai\"\u003erevenue for the second quarter was down 15% year-over-year\u003c/a\u003e. offered at a discounted price for the first time in the UK, Ireland, Germany, Austria, and India.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe console\u0026#39;s prices have been slashed to \u0026pound;404.99 (a reduction of \u0026pound;75) in the UK and Ireland, and to \u0026euro;474.99 (a reduction of \u0026euro;75) in Germany and Austria, according to $399.99.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMoreover, Sony recently announced that the PS5 has been a massive success, selling over 40 million units as of July 16, 2023, though it slightly trails the sales pace of the PS4 due to the previous semiconductor shortage. While the PS4 took 30 months to reach this milestone, the PS5 accomplished this feat in 32 months.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs of now, there is no information regarding a discount in the U.S., but Enough AI Chips For Its Data Centers\" - CNBC","teaser":"\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2023/07/28/microsoft-annual-report-highlights-importance-of-gpus.html\" title=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2023/07/28/microsoft-annual-report-highlights-importance-of-gpus.html\"\u003ehttps://www.cnbc.com/2023/07/28/microsoft-annual-report-highlights-importance-of-gpus.html\u003c/a\u003e\n\n\u0026nbsp;\n\n\n\tMicrosoft updated a risk factor in its annual report with a reference to the importance of securing graphics","body":"\u003cdiv\u003ehttps://www.cnbc.com/2023/07/28/microsoft-annual-report-highlights-importance-of-gpus.html\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMicrosoft updated a risk factor in its annual report with a reference to the importance of securing graphics processing units for its data centers.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe company has been ramping up capital expenditures, including for GPUs, to meet rising demand for cloud-based artificial-intelligence services.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/MSFT/\"\u003eMicrosoft\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;is emphasizing to investors that graphics processing units are a critical raw material for its fast-growing cloud business. In its\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/789019/000095017023035122/msft-20230630.htm\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eannual report\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;released late on Thursday, the software maker added language about GPUs to a risk factor for outages that can arise if it can\u0026rsquo;t get the infrastructure it needs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe language reflects the\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2023/07/25/microsoft-is-in-the-lead-with-cloud-based-ai-workloads-nadella-says.html\"\u003egrowing demand\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;at the top technology companies for the hardware that\u0026rsquo;s necessary to provide artificial intelligence capabilities to smaller businesses.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAI, and specifically generative AI that involves generating human-like text, speech, videos and images in response to people\u0026rsquo;s input, has become more popular this year, after startup OpenAI\u0026rsquo;s ChatGPT chatbot\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2023/02/08/what-is-chatgpt-viral-ai-chatbot-at-heart-of-microsoft-google-fight.html\"\u003ebecame a hit\u003c/a\u003e. That has benefited GPU makers such as\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/NVDA/\"\u003eNvidia\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and, to a smaller extent,\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/AMD/\"\u003eAMD\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026ldquo;Our datacenters depend on the availability of permitted and buildable land,\u0026nbsp;predictable energy, networking supplies, and servers, including graphics processing units (\u0026ldquo;GPUs\u0026rdquo;) and other components,\u0026rdquo; Microsoft said in\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/789019/000095017023035122/msft-20230630.htm\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eits report\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;for the 2023 fiscal year, which ended on June 30.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat\u0026rsquo;s one of three passages mentioning GPUs in the regulatory filing. They were not mentioned once in the previous year\u0026rsquo;s report. Such language has not appeared in recent annual reports from other large technology companies, such as\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/GOOGL/\"\u003eAlphabet\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/AAPL/\"\u003eApple\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/AMZN/\"\u003eAmazon\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/META/\"\u003eMeta\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOpenAI relies on Microsoft\u0026rsquo;s Azure cloud to perform the computations for ChatGPT and various AI models, as part of a complex partnership. Microsoft has also begun using OpenAI\u0026rsquo;s models to enhance existing products, such as its Outlook and Word applications and the Bing search engine, with generative AI.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThose efforts and the interest in ChatGPT have led Microsoft to seek more GPUs than it had expected.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026ldquo;I am thrilled that Microsoft announced\u0026nbsp;Azure\u0026nbsp;is opening private previews to their H100 AI supercomputer,\u0026rdquo; Jensen Huang, Nvidia\u0026rsquo;s CEO, said at his company\u0026rsquo;s GTC developer conference in March.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMicrosoft has begun looking outside its own data centers to secure enough capacity, signing an\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2023/06/01/microsoft-inks-deal-with-coreweave-to-meet-openai-cloud-demand.html\"\u003eagreement with Nvidia-backed CoreWeave\u003c/a\u003e, which rents out GPUs to third-party developers as a cloud service.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt the same time, Microsoft has spent years building its own custom AI processor. All the attention on ChatGPT has led Microsoft to speed up the deployment of its chip,\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"https://www.theinformation.com/articles/microsoft-readies-ai-chip-as-machine-learning-costs-surge\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eThe Information\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;reported in April, citing unnamed sources.\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2018/05/08/google-launches-tpu-3-point-0-third-version-of-ai-chips.html\"\u003eAlphabet\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2018/11/28/aws-launches-inferentia-ai-chip.html\"\u003eAmazon\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and Meta have all announced their own AI chips over the past decade.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMicrosoft expects to increase its capital expenditures sequentially this quarter, to pay for data centers, standard central processing units, networking hardware and GPUs, Amy Hood, the company\u0026rsquo;s finance chief, said Tuesday on a conference call with analysts. \u0026ldquo;It\u0026rsquo;s overall increases of acceleration of overall capacity,\u0026rdquo; she said.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n","url":"https://www.benzinga.com/news/23/07/33445494/microsoft-warns-of-service-disruptions-if-it-cant-get-enough-ai-chips-for-its-data-centers-cnbc","image":null,"image_thumb":null,"image_large":null,"channels":[{"tid":57,"name":"News","description":""}],"stocks":[{"tid":12200,"name":"MSFT","description":"Microsoft"}],"tags":[],"campaigns":"\n  var bzCampaign_top = {\n    id: 534,\n    nid: 33445494\n  };\n\n  if(typeof bzCampaignStats == 'function') {\n    // If/stats is enabled, fire them\n    bzCampaignStats(bzCampaign_top.cid, bzCampaign_top.nid);\n  }\n  var bzCampaignJS_top = \"\u003chr \\/\u003e\\r\\n\u003ch4 style=\\\"text-align: center;\\\"\u003eSecure Your Financial Future\u003c\\/h4\u003e\\r\\n\u003cp style=\\\"text-align: left; padding: 30px;\\\"\u003eHidden gems are waiting to be found in this market! }"},{"id":33445377,"author":"Alex Coffey","created":"Fri, 28 Jul 2023 11:32:40 -0400","updated":"Fri, 28 Jul 2023 11:32:42 -0400","title":"August Outlook: Jackson Hole Beckons For Fed, But Could Events Reprise Last Year's Market Stampede?","teaser":"\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eThe heat dome that\u0026rsquo;s settled over much of the country this summer might have you wishing for a trip to the mountains, and that\u0026rsquo;s exactly what the Federal Reserve gets in August at its approaching Jackson Hole symposium.\u003c/p\u003e","body":"\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eThe heat dome that\u0026rsquo;s settled over much of the country this summer might have you wishing for a trip to the mountains, and that\u0026rsquo;s exactly what the Federal Reserve gets in August at its approaching Jackson Hole symposium.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eHowever, just the words \u0026ldquo;Jackson Hole\u0026rdquo; might trigger an investor flashback to last year\u0026rsquo;s affair, when Fed Chairman Jerome Powell\u0026rsquo;s hawkish comments scotched a much-needed market rally. It\u0026rsquo;s not clear yet if he\u0026rsquo;ll arrive in Wyoming feeling any differently on August 24, but earnings and data between now and then could provide clues.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eUntil late July, Wall Street had been on a roll, partially on hopes the Fed might be near the end of its 16-month rate hike cycle that\u0026rsquo;s raised the target range for interest rates by 500 basis points. Stocks recently hit 15-month highs as U.S. inflation eased and job gains appeared to slow, but the Fed still raised rates 25 basis points at its July 26 meeting. Chances of a follow-up hike in September started to heat up a bit in the futures market.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eAugust puts the focus firmly on the Fed and includes earnings from corporate bellwethers, including\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eApple\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(NASDAQ:\u0026nbsp;AAPL),\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eNvidia\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(NASDAQ: \u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/nvda#NASDAQ\"\u003eNVDA\u003c/a\u003e), and\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eBerkshire Hathaway\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(NYSE: \u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/brk-a#NYSE\"\u003eBRK-A\u003c/a\u003e). August is also the first full month of trading following the recent special rebalancing of the\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eNasdaq-100\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026reg;\u003cstrong\u003e\u0026nbsp;Index\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(NDX), which Nasdaq engineered to reduce the impact on the index from its largest components including AAPL and NVDA. Some analysts expect this to put pressure on mega-caps as mutual funds ease exposure to those stocks to match the updated index weighting.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCooler breeze in Wyoming this time?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eThe Fed\u0026rsquo;s Jackson Hole Symposium runs from August 24 \u0026ndash; 26 and is titled \u0026ldquo;Structural Shifts in the Global Economy.\u0026rdquo; Each year, Powell makes a speech in Jackson Hole, and investors tend to parse words for clues about future policy and economic metrics. Last year, Powell used the speech to warn that the fight against inflation would bring \u0026ldquo;some pain.\u0026rdquo; And it did; the Fed launched a series of 75-basis-point rate hikes that sent Wall Street running for cover.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eIn mid-August last year, the\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eS\u0026amp;P 500\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026reg;\u003cstrong\u003e\u0026nbsp;index\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(SPX) closed at a summer peak just above 4,300 before Powell spoke, then cratered to 3,577 by mid-October. That was the lowest it got last year before rebounding 27% by mid-July.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eBad memories aside, one could argue things are very different now, and there\u0026rsquo;s no need for fire and brimstone from Powell. Inflation in June\u0026mdash;the last reading available\u0026mdash;fell to its lowest level in more than two years, though it remains well above the Fed\u0026rsquo;s 2% target. And the Fed\u0026rsquo;s current target interest rate range of 5.25% to 5% following the July 26 hike puts rates within one 25-basis-point increase of where the Fed said in June they\u0026rsquo;d peak this year. Many analysts believe the Fed ultimately won\u0026rsquo;t raise rates any further than it is now despite that projection from June. All this helps explain why investors became much more bullish about stocks in June and July.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eAugust could tell a different story\u0026mdash;or not\u0026mdash;depending on company reporting and key data like the August 4\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eNonfarm Payrolls\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;report for July. The Fed remains concerned about a labor market that\u0026rsquo;s still hot and drove wages up more than 4% in June from a year earlier.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eInflation, jobs data key in August\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eIt\u0026rsquo;s hard to slow inflation when companies face pressure to raise wages. That often means businesses choosing between raising prices to cover the rising cost of labor or taking a punishment on profit. What the Fed wants to prevent is a so-called \u0026ldquo;wage-price spiral\u0026rdquo; where higher wages lead to higher prices, which lead to higher wages, and so on.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eSlowing jobs growth would likely help prevent that, but until June of this year, each monthly payrolls report came in much higher than analysts expected. The main reason for that is a \u0026ldquo;services\u0026rdquo; sector\u0026mdash;hotels, restaurant meals, plane tickets\u0026mdash;which remains strong as consumers keep spending amid low unemployment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eJune jobs growth cooled to just 209,000, and there were downward revisions to the prior two reports. A repeat on August 4 would possibly ease rate and inflation fears, which remain on investors\u0026rsquo; minds judging from recent strength in Treasury note yields.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eThe July\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eConsumer Price Index\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(CPI) data the week of August 11 is another huge report to watch after total CPI tumbled to just 3% in June. Even the more closely watched core CPI reading, which subtracts volatile food and energy prices, dropped from 5.3% in May to a lower-than-expected 4.8% in June.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eHowever, investors should keep the July CPI report in context, especially its year-over-year data. June\u0026rsquo;s report had an easy comparison against a very hot report the previous year. That\u0026rsquo;s not the case in July and may mean a more substantial increase in annual growth. The month-to-month numbers may be more useful as a gauge of how well the Fed\u0026rsquo;s inflation battle is going.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eAnother economic gauge in August is company results. Earnings season got off to a fair start, although analysts expect a 9% decline in year-over-year\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eS\u0026amp;P 500\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;earnings per share, according to FactSet. About 75% of S\u0026amp;P 500 companies beat Wall Street\u0026rsquo;s estimates in the first two weeks of earnings season, near the 74% 10-year average.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"simple-image  -  - -\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"img-zoom zoom-wrapper-2018\" href=\"https://tickertapecdn.tdameritrade.com/assets/images/pages/lg/august-outlook-chart.png\"\u003e\u003cimg alt=\"\" class=\"img-fluid\" src=\"https://tickertapecdn.tdameritrade.com/assets/images/pages/md/august-outlook-chart.png\" /\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"image-caption\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePLAYING CATCH-UP\u003c/strong\u003e: After lagging the S\u0026amp;P 500 index (SPX\u0026mdash;candlesticks) for months, the Dow Jones Industrial Average\u0026reg; ($DJI\u0026mdash;purple line) has advanced more quickly in the last few weeks as a rally once focused mainly on heavyweight tech broadened to embrace industrials and financial stocks better represented in the $DJI. Data source: S\u0026amp;P Dow Jones Indices. Chart source:\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"https://www.tdameritrade.com/tools-and-platforms/thinkorswim.page\"\u003ethinkorswim\u0026reg; platform\u003c/a\u003e.\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003eFor illustrative purposes only. Past performance does not guarantee future results.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eTech titans step to the plate\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eApple\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;hit $3 trillion in market capitalization in July for the first time since early 2022 and is expected to report on Thursday, August 3. Expectations might be elevated considering how far the stock has come this year. Many high-flying stocks have seen their values clipped after reporting as \u0026ldquo;buy the rumor, sell the fact\u0026rdquo; sentiment picks up on Wall Street.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eLast time out, AAPL beat Wall Street\u0026rsquo;s expectations, driven by solid iPhone sales. At the same time, Mac, Services, and iPad revenue failed to meet analysts\u0026rsquo; forecasts. That means those products could come under scrutiny when AAPL reports in early August\u0026mdash;especially services, which generate so much profit. The question is whether AAPL is increasingly dependent on iPhone to keep earnings from slipping.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eOn the product side, investors might be on the lookout for updates on AAPL\u0026rsquo;s recently introduced Vision Pro headset and 15-inch MacBook Air laptop. Also, look out for potential updates on the iPhone 15, which according to\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003eBarron\u0026rsquo;s\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;is expected to launch sometime in September. Anything the company says about artificial intelligence (AI) might get noticed too.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNvidia\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003eis another trillion-dollar market-cap tech company reporting in August, and its earnings will be under a microscope after the semiconductor firm shocked Wall Street with its prodigious guidance. Though shares pulled back a bit recently, NVDA is one of the top performers so far this year with gains well above 100%, and its coming earnings might show if NVDA was able to pull off revenue feats it promised last time out. NVDA is scheduled to report after the close on August 23.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eAs you\u0026rsquo;ll recall, NVDA said in its last earnings release that it expects fiscal 2024\u0026nbsp;Q2 revenue of $11 billion, up from $7.19 billion in fiscal Q1. \u0026ldquo;The computer industry is going through two simultaneous transitions\u0026mdash;accelerated computing and generative AI,\u0026rdquo; said Jensen Huang, founder and CEO of NVDA, in its Q1 press release. \u0026ldquo;A trillion dollars of installed global data center infrastructure will transition from general purpose to accelerated computing as companies race to apply generative AI into every product, service, and business process.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eNVDA and other semiconductor shares fell in late July after\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eTaiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(TSM) issued weak guidance amid softer demand for electronic devices. Some analysts say Nvidia might be less exposed to overall chip market weakness because of the strength in AI, where Nvidia has strong market share.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eMarket leadership changing\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eIn late July, the SPX slowed from steep climbs earlier this summer. That\u0026rsquo;s not necessarily a sign of weakness. The mega-cap heavyweights that make up about 30% of the SPX by market capitalization began to pull back after their long ascent, while smaller stocks in the index rose.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eThose smaller stocks don\u0026rsquo;t have as large an impact on the overall index, but their rebound reflects a broadening of the rally that could be a healthy sign after many months where info tech shouldered most of the load. The question is whether this pattern continues once August begins.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRetreats in trillion-dollar names like AAPL,\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eMicrosoft\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(NASDAQ: \u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/msft#NASDAQ\"\u003eMSFT\u003c/a\u003e), and NVDA coincided with improved performance for sectors like financials, industrials, and energy, many of which struggled earlier this year. One problem with this scenario is it could mean less upside for the SPX because its performance depends heavily on mega-caps. Other sectors would need to rise an enormous amount,\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003eBarron\u0026rsquo;s\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;noted, to move the index up meaningfully in the second half if tech takes a powder.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eYields, oil could squeeze\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eTwo other things to watch in August that raised eyebrows in July are Treasury note yields and crude oil (/CL).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eTreasury yields retreated in mid-July from above 4% for the\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003e10-year Treasury yield\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003e(TNX) early that month but remained at an uncomfortable high above 3.8%. High yields can sometimes act as a brake on stocks, especially small-cap stocks and growth firms that rely more on borrowing to grow their business.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eAnd the inversion between the 10-year Treasury note yield and the\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003e2-year Treasury note yield\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;stayed steeply elevated at above 100 basis points. This inversion, now in its second year, typically means investors are taking a defensive stance ahead of possible economic stress.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eSo far this earnings season, executives and some analysts sounded relatively sanguine about possible recession, but a series of soft data in mid-to-late July increased worries. U.S. housing, retail sales, and manufacturing showed signs of weakness and so did earnings from major companies like\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eAmerican Express\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(AXP) and\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eCSX\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(CSX). Meanwhile, rising near-term Treasury yields put pressure on growth sector stocks, which tend to rely more on borrowing to grow their businesses.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eAdditionally, China\u0026mdash;sometimes thought of as the world\u0026rsquo;s \u0026ldquo;factory\u0026rdquo;\u0026mdash;saw lighter-than-expected Q2\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eGross Domestic Product\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(GDP) growth, a sign to some economists that U.S. and European companies may be hit by falling demand for their products.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p3\"\u003eWeakness in China might normally mean a drop in crude oil prices, but instead,\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003e/CL\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;is up about 10% from recent lows as OPEC\u0026rsquo;s production cuts finally seem to be filtering through the supply chain. Any further rise could take some sizzle out of the U.S. economy and stock market as the calendar ticks toward back-to-school season and the Fed heads out West.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTD Ameritrade\u0026reg; commentary for educational purposes only. 11:27:33 -0400","updated":"Fri, 28 Jul 2023 11:27:35 -0400","title":"Price Pressure Eased In June, Fueling Early Wall Street Gains, But BoJ Rate Policy Move Rattles Market","teaser":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e(Friday market open)\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003eWelcome signs of easing U.S. inflation propelled Wall Street to early gains Friday, but the market remains rattled following a policy tweak earlier from the\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eBank of Japan\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(BoJ) and worries about the\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eFederal Reserve\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;potentially tightening further.\u003c/p\u003e","body":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e(Friday market open)\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003eWelcome signs of easing U.S. inflation propelled Wall Street to early gains Friday, but the market remains rattled following a policy tweak earlier from the\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eBank of Japan\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(BoJ) and worries about the\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eFederal Reserve\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;potentially tightening further.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eToday\u0026rsquo;s\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003ePersonal Consumption Expenditures\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(PCE) prices report showed the core prices rising 0.2% in June, down from 0.3% in May. That was in line with expectations and more evidence of a softer pricing environment. Core prices strip out food and energy. Core PCE rose 4.1% annually in June, down from 4.6% in May.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eU.S. Treasury yields fell slightly early Friday despite the BoJ\u0026rsquo;s surprise tweak to its yield-curve control policy. The BoJ\u0026rsquo;s official 0% target on 10-year government bonds didn\u0026rsquo;t change, but it now calls the -0.5% to 0.5% range it has in place \u0026ldquo;reference points,\u0026rdquo; not \u0026ldquo;rigid limits.\u0026rdquo; The BoJ said this would give it \u0026ldquo;greater flexibility.\u0026rdquo; Economists said this was the equivalent of Japan raising the cap to 1%, and Japanese stocks declined.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eReports that Japan might make such a decision rattled U.S. stocks on Thursday as spikes across the U.S. Treasury curve seemed to spook investors. Strong U.S. economic data released early on Thursday generated additional pressure, highlighting the need for the Fed to be more aggressive in pushing growth and inflation down if they experience a resurgence, says Kevin Gordon, senior investment strategist at the Schwab Center for Financial Research.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRising yields typically hurt growth stocks and smaller companies that may depend more on borrowing for future growth. That might explain why the\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eRussell 2000\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(RUT) small-cap index fell most dramatically yesterday. Sectors like utilities and real estate, which try to attract investors with dividend yields, also got hit by Thursday\u0026rsquo;s Treasury yield gains.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTechnically, yesterday was an \u0026ldquo;outside day\u0026rdquo; on the charts for the\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eS\u0026amp;P 500\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u0026reg;\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u0026nbsp;Index\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(SPX), meaning it ventured both above the previous day\u0026rsquo;s high and below the previous day\u0026rsquo;s low. This one looked negative in that the SPX reached a peak very early Thursday and then finished sharply below Wednesday\u0026rsquo;s close, illustrating investor uncertainty. Such a move can sometimes draw technical sellers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eMorning rush\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003e10-year Treasury note yield\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(TNX) fell 4 basis points to 3.96%.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe\u003cstrong\u003e\u0026nbsp;U.S. Dollar Index\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;($DXY) fell to 101.5.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCboe\u0026nbsp;Volatility\u0026nbsp;Index\u003c/strong\u003e\u003ca name=\"_Hlk140761640\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026reg;\u0026nbsp;(VIX) futures dropped to 13.51.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWTI Crude Oil\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003e(/CL) jumped to $80.16 per barrel.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eJust in\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePCE prices in June rose 0.2% for both the headline and the core numbers, which is in line with Wall Street\u0026rsquo;s consensus. The core figure showed sequential improvement, falling from May\u0026rsquo;s 0.3% rise.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe core data, which strips out volatile food and energy costs, is the one the Fed watches most closely. It\u0026rsquo;s been \u0026ldquo;sticky\u0026rdquo; at 4.6% to 4.7% on an annual basis most of the year. Core PCE had been expected to rise 4.2% year-over-year in June, but slowed to just 4.1%, down from 4.6% in May. That\u0026rsquo;s likely to be seen as progress on the price front, though it remains well above the Fed\u0026rsquo;s 2% goal. Headline PCE prices rose 3% in June, down from 3.8% in May.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJune\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003ePersonal Income\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;and\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003ePersonal Spending\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;also hit the tape this morning. Personal spending\u0026rsquo;s 0.5% climb was more than analysts had expected, perhaps reflecting low unemployment and improving consumer sentiment. The final July\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eUniversity of Michigan Consumer Sentiment\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;report is due out after the open and analysts expect a headline of 72.6, unchanged from the preliminary July report and up from 64.4 in June, according to Trading Economics.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWage growth was up 0.6% in June\u0026mdash;the fastest increase since January. This is a key driver of overall income growth and speaks to resilience of the labor market. The Employment Cost Index saw a 4.5% year-over-year growth rate in June, the fastest on record aside from during the pandemic. This is probably still too hot for the Fed, which has been trying to cool the labor market.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eEye on the Fed\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFutures trading indicates a 20% probability that the FOMC will raise rates at its September meeting, according to the\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eCME FedWatch Tool.\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;The probability for November is close to 27%. Those were basically unchanged from yesterday despite today\u0026rsquo;s data.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn one positive sign the Fed might have noted, the Q2\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eGross Domestic Product\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(GDP) deflator, which measures inflation in the price of goods and services produced in the U.S., fell to a 2.2% annualized rate, the lowest since Q2 2020 and a sign that prices appear to be softening. It peaked at 9% in Q2 2022.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDespite that, Treasury yields rocketed on Thursday following better-than-expected U.S. Q2 GDP growth and anticipation that the BoJ might address its yield-curve control policy, which has kept yields from rising despite growth in the Japanese economy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe U.S. 10-year Treasury note yield jumped a sharp 14 basis points Thursday to trade above 4% for the first time since July 10 after falling all the way to 3.73% on July 18. The 2-year Treasury note yield, which is more sensitive to the Fed\u0026rsquo;s rate policy, rose 9 basis points to 4.92%. If Japanese buyers stayed home to invest in their own country\u0026rsquo;s bonds, it would likely hurt U.S. Treasury prices, sending yields higher (yields move the opposite way of the underlying note\u0026rsquo;s price).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRising Treasury yields could also indicate growing fear of another rate hike after the Fed said this week it would take a meeting-by-meeting, data-driven approach to interest rate policy. The futures market still builds in high probability of the Fed pausing in September, with a better chance that it could raise rates another 25 basis points in November. If it does so in either month, rates would reach the Fed\u0026rsquo;s projected 2023 terminal, or peak, level between 5.5% and 5.75%. They\u0026rsquo;re already at their loftiest point since 2001.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eStocks in Spotlight\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe earnings car hit a few slippery spots this week. Two notable examples are the market\u0026rsquo;s disappointment with\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eMicrosoft\u0026rsquo;s\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(NASDAQ: \u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/msft#NASDAQ\"\u003eMSFT\u003c/a\u003e) cloud market outlook and a selloff of\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eSpotify\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(NYSE: \u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/spot#NYSE\"\u003eSPOT\u003c/a\u003e) shares after the music streaming company\u0026rsquo;s earnings miss and weak guidance.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor the most part, however, it\u0026rsquo;s been a smooth road, highlighted most recently by\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eIntel\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003e(NASDAQ: \u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/intc#NASDAQ\"\u003eINTC\u003c/a\u003e) and\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eFord\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(NYSE: \u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/f#NYSE\"\u003eF\u003c/a\u003e): Both surpassed Wall Street\u0026rsquo;s expectations late on Thursday and are getting premarket trading boosts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIntel was the bigger surprise, posting a quarterly profit when analysts had expected a loss and citing its positive position to capitalize on artificial intelligence (AI) growth. The company\u0026rsquo;s cost savings plan contributed to the earnings improvement, Intel said in a press release. Like many info tech companies, it has reduced headcount over the last year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFord had a mostly strong quarter, but it the huge losses it\u0026rsquo;s taking on electric vehicles (EVs) continue to raise eyebrows.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhat to Watch\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTalking technicals:\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003eOn Thursday, the SPX spent some time above 4,600, a level that marked technical resistance going back 16 months. In early 2022, the SPX tested that point on rally attempts three times following the record high it set near 4,800 soon after the new year began. It failed each time and fell from there. The 4,600 level marks the last resistance below the all-time high, says Nathan Peterson, director of derivatives analysis at the Schwab Center for Financial Research. The first step is registering a close above 4,600 and then monitoring for sustainability above that level in the following days for confirmation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf Thursday\u0026rsquo;s sharp retreat is evidence, 4,600 still represents a challenging point for the SPX. It will continue to be an important level to watch on any rally.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"simple-image  -  - -\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"img-zoom zoom-wrapper-2018\" href=\"https://tickertapecdn.tdameritrade.com/assets/images/pages/lg/chart-7-28.png\"\u003e\u003cimg alt=\"\" class=\"img-fluid\" src=\"https://tickertapecdn.tdameritrade.com/assets/images/pages/md/chart-7-28.png\" /\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"image-caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCHART OF THE DAY:\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBIRDS OF A FEATHER\u003c/strong\u003e. Rising Treasury yields (TNX\u0026mdash;candlesticks) often push crude oil futures (/CL-purple line) lower. That hasn\u0026rsquo;t been the case this month, as low supplies of crude supported that market and raised concerns about inflation, which in turn may have helped push Treasury yields higher.\u0026nbsp;Chart source: The\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"https://www.tdameritrade.com/tools-and-platforms/thinkorswim.page\"\u003ethinkorswim\u0026reg; platform from TD\u0026nbsp;Ameritrade\u003c/a\u003e.\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003eFor illustrative purposes only. Past performance does not guarantee future results.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThinking cap\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIdeas to mull as you trade or invest\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRabbit, meet hat:\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;Less impressive revenue growth for S\u0026amp;P 500 companies reporting to date partially reflects easing inflation and its impact on pricing power. With that in mind, how did more than 80% of S\u0026amp;P 500 companies reporting through mid-week beat analysts\u0026rsquo; bottom-line estimates? First, analysts set a low bar for earnings results, making estimates easier to beat. The average earnings per share (EPS) estimate is -9% for S\u0026amp;P 500 companies on a year-over-year basis, FactSet says. Better-than-expected EPS could also reflect cost-cutting many companies took earlier this year, as seen yesterday with Intel.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMargin call\u003c/strong\u003e: The margin pressure we noted yesterday isn\u0026rsquo;t across the board. Some sectors are doing well on that front, including industrials, consumer discretionary, and real estate. Sectors accounting for much of the margin pressure include energy, materials, and health care, FactSet notes. Lower crude oil and natural gas prices versus a year ago likely took a big bite out of energy\u0026rsquo;s profit margins, for instance. Many analysts think Q2 might represent the margin trough, and that\u0026rsquo;s one factor behind estimates for stronger earnings growth in the second half.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eInflation fears fueled:\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;One price metric the Fed and other central banks have little control over is commodities, and the recent three-month high in front-month CME crude oil futures (/CL) has fueled worries. There\u0026rsquo;s certainly a chance that despite central banks\u0026rsquo; best-laid plans, the price of crude\u0026mdash;a product that permeates nearly every aspect of the global economy\u0026mdash;could keep inflation elevated. One argument against that is a futures market that\u0026rsquo;s in backwardation, meaning contracts farther out are lower than the current price. This is partly seasonal, as crude prices typically peak in the Northern Hemisphere\u0026rsquo;s summer and U.S. \u0026ldquo;driving season\u0026rdquo; only has about a month left. While spot crude prices of $80 per barrel might fuel inflation concerns, a futures market that prices in $76 by early next year suggests less reason to worry. Also, the recent production cuts by Saudi Arabia mean more crude is being left in the ground every month, which potentially could mean an extra supply cushion. Strong demand, however, is keeping prices elevated.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCalendar\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eJuly 31:\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;July Chicago PMI and expected earnings from CNA Financial (CNA) and Tenet Healthcare (THC)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAug. 1\u003c/strong\u003e: July ISM Manufacturing Index and June Job Openings, and expected earnings from Altria (MO), Caterpillar (CAT), Illinois Tool (ITW), Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Merck (MRK), Pfizer (PFE), Uber (UBER), Allstate (ALL), and Starbucks (SBUX)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAug. 2:\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;ADP Employment Change, and expected earnings from DuPont (DD), Kraft Heinz (KHC), Yum Brands (YUM), Clorox (CLX), PayPal (PYPL), and Shopify (SHOP)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAug. 3:\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;June Factory Orders, July ISM Non-Manufacturing Index, and expected earnings from Amazon (AMZN), Apple (AAPL), Coinbase (COIN), Amgen (AMGN), Alibaba (BABA), Hyatt Hotels (H), and Kellogg (K)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAug. 4:\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;July Nonfarm Payrolls and expected earnings from Dominion Energy (D), Enbridge (ENB), and Corebridge Financial (CRBG)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eTD Ameritrade\u0026reg; commentary for educational purposes only. class=\\\"access-the-benzinga-insider-report-usually-47-month-for-only-0-99-span\\\"\u003eAccess the Benzinga Insider Report, usually $47\\/month,\u003c\\/span\u003e\\r\\n                \u003cspan class=\\\"access-the-benzinga-insider-report-usually-47-month-for-only-0-99-span2\\\"\u003efor only $0.99!\u003c\\/span\u003e\\r\\n            \u003c\\/span\u003e\\r\\n        \u003c\\/div\u003e\\r\\n }"},{"id":33444916,"author":"The Bamboo Works","created":"Fri, 28 Jul 2023 11:14:29 -0400","updated":"Fri, 28 Jul 2023 11:16:24 -0400","title":"Not Quite Closure: Alibaba Exit Leaves Questions For SenseTime","teaser":"\u003ch4\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eKey Takeaways:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h4\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cul\u003e\r\n\t\u003cli\u003eSenseTime\u0026rsquo;s battered share price enjoyed a brief bounce after Alibaba completed a stake selloff, removing some of the uncertainty surrounding the stock\u003c/li\u003e\r","body":"\u003ch4\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eKey Takeaways:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSenseTime\u0026rsquo;s battered share price enjoyed a brief bounce after Alibaba completed a stake selloff, removing some of the uncertainty surrounding the stock\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eInvestors will pay close attention to SenseTime\u0026rsquo;s performance in the first half of the year, looking for any progress in tackling the problems of rising trade receivables, falling revenue and surging costs\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy Fai Pui\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChinese tech company\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eSenseTime Group Inc.\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(0020.HK) was quick to join the chatbot frenzy with a suite of AI tools, but its share price has been rapidly going in the opposite direction to other big names in artificial intelligence.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAI has been an investment magnet since OpenAI, backed by\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eMicrosoft\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(NASDAQ: \u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/msft#NASDAQ\"\u003eMSFT\u003c/a\u003e), launched its ChatGPT last year, heralding a new age of transformative technology. The enthusiasm has since lifted AI-related stocks in major markets around the world, with Microsoft,\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eNvidia\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(NASDAQ: \u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/nvda#NASDAQ\"\u003eNVDA\u003c/a\u003e) and\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eApple\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eInc.\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(NASDAQ: \u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/aapl#NASDAQ\"\u003eAAPL\u003c/a\u003e) scaling fresh heights.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut it is a different story in Hong Kong, where some investors are cashing out of AI. Primary investors in China\u0026rsquo;s\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eSenseTime\u003c/strong\u003e, which brands itself as a pure AI company\u003cstrong\u003e,\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003ehave sold down their stakes over several months\u003cstrong\u003e,\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003eslashing 20% off the stock value since the start of the year, to the dismay of other investors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn July 21, the share dived 5.6% in a single day. It dropped another 3% the next day, when a mass of sell orders in the first five minutes of trade sent the price to a new low for the year of HK$1.61. But the share suddenly and unexpectedly rebounded that morning, surging 14.2% in half an hour from HK$1.61 to HK$1.84.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJust as investors were puzzling over the price moves, the company made an after-hours\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"https://www1.hkexnews.hk/listedco/listconews/sehk/2023/0721/2023072100199.pdf\"\u003eannouncement\u003c/a\u003e. The market learned that Taobao Holding Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary of\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eAlibaba\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGroup\u0026nbsp;\u003c/strong\u003e(NYSE: \u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/baba#NYSE\"\u003eBABA\u003c/a\u003e), had sold all its remaining class B shares in SenseTime, bringing the tech giant\u0026rsquo;s five-year investment in the AI company to a close.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNews that Alibaba had definitively completed its SenseTime retreat triggered a relief rally, easing some of the uncertainty that had been weighing on the AI firm\u0026rsquo;s stock, according to Kenny Wen, KGI Asia\u0026rsquo;s head of investment strategy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026ldquo;SenseTime was under pressure due to Alibaba\u0026rsquo;s continual selloff. With the full exit, one source of strain was lifted, and this helped explain why the stock reversed its decline last Friday,\u0026rdquo; he said.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlibaba was one of the core investors in SenseTime when the firm launched a Series C financing round in 2018, raising $600 million. The investors, which included Singapore\u0026rsquo;s Temasek sovereign wealth fund, piled in at $0.153 (HK$1.19) per share. In April this year, the AI excitement from ChatGPT boosted the SenseTime price from HK$2.4 to HK$3.7.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlibaba has made handsome profits by cashing out from the peak. On April 11, it announced a sale of 40 million shares at HK$3.452, pocketing HK$138 million ($17.7 million) in proceeds. The SenseTime share price began to wilt under the pressure. Alibaba sold another 70 million shares on June 5 for HK$154 million, and 10 days later it offloaded another 50 million at HK$2.267 to net HK$113 million.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy July 6, Alibaba had sold 557 million shares at an average price of HK$1.82, thereby coming away with HK$1.014 billion. Factoring in the remaining holdings sold last week, it has extracted more than HK$1.9 billion from its investment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIndependent analyst Ivan Chow linked the decision to pull out of SenseTime with Alibaba\u0026rsquo;s plans to split into multiple units and its eagerness to avoid any suggestion of monopolistic practices that could threaten its future prospects.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs China\u0026rsquo;s biggest provider of visual software, SenseTime has rolled out a host of AI products including mobile AI services, autonomous driving solutions, and platforms for cities and enterprises. Its business is built around four pillars: smart city, smart life, smart vehicles and smart business. In April, the company debuted its proprietary AI architecture \u0026ldquo;SenseNova\u0026rdquo; together with a ChatGPT-like product called \u0026ldquo;SenseChat\u0026rdquo;, which can write text and computer code and is even able to provide medical consultations. Keen to capitalize on the AI frenzy, it also introduced \u0026ldquo;SenseMirage\u0026rdquo;, which generates images from words, and \u0026ldquo;SenseAvatar\u0026rdquo;, an AI-based film platform.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eStill Bleeding\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut the broad suite of AI products has not bolstered the share price, as investors fret about SenseTime\u0026rsquo;s declining revenue, rising trade receivables and sustained losses, according to KGI Asia\u0026rsquo;s Wen.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026ldquo;Despite their bullish sentiment about tech stocks, they would rather choose the big names such as Alibaba and\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eTencent\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(0700.HK) instead,\u0026rdquo; he said.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSenseTime was still stuck in the red last year with a net loss of 6.09 billion yuan ($850 million). The net loss was nearly 65% smaller than in 2021, but the company\u0026rsquo;s non-IFRS adjusted loss surged by a whopping 234% to 4.74 billion yuan. Even more concerning was a 19% drop in revenue, driven by steep falls in income from two of its key businesses. Revenue in the smart business category fell by a quarter and the smart city income stream logged a nearly 49% drop, offsetting rising revenue in the other two segments, smart life and smart vehicles.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSenseTime blamed the effects of the pandemic, which had increased its trade receivables, or outstanding payments by customers. Receivables with a timeframe of one to two years jumped 1.3 times to 3.245 billion yuan and three-year receivables ballooned by 524% from 101 million yuan in 2021 to 630 million yuan.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWen believes it will be crucial for the company to post an upbeat performance for the first half of the year, after pandemic controls were lifted. Investors will be on the lookout for any improvement in the figures for trade receivables, as well as any management progress in cutting costs to staunch the flow of red ink, he said.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn July 13, China issued interim policies on the generative AI industry that will go into effect on August 15. The text struck a more positive note than an earlier outline, with the stated aim of promoting healthy and effective growth in the sector. Without any hint of the harsh tech regulation of recent years, the blueprint offers clues to the direction of travel for China\u0026rsquo;s AI industry.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut analyst Chow thinks international investors will still be cautious about SenseTime, amid tensions between China and the U.S. over potentially sensitive technology.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026ldquo;Despite attractive valuations, foreign funds or investors might steer clear of the stock due to the company being sanctioned by the U.S. and not being included in the MSCI index,\u0026rdquo; he said, adding that appetite for the stock would be further dampened by a U.S. Treasury requirement for U.S. investment funds to provide information about their Chinese holdings. Unless the relationship between the two countries improves, SenseTime stock would continue to struggle, he said.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother company,\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eCloudwalk Technology\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(688327.SH), also ranks among China\u0026rsquo;s big four AI stocks, and is more highly valued by investors than SenseTime, judging from comparative price-to-sales (P/S) ratios. Cloudwalk is listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange with a P/S ratio of 47.51 times, way more than SenseTime\u0026rsquo;s multiple of 13.4.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMoreover, SenseTime has been facing selling pressure from other big-name investors aside from Alibaba. Japan\u0026rsquo;s\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003eSoftbank\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;(9984.T), which has been reporting losses for five straight quarters, also sold 50 million SenseTime shares in April.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow that Alibaba\u0026rsquo;s divestment is complete, the stock price moves may hinge on whether Softbank decides to free up cash by selling more of its shares.\u003c/p\u003e\n","url":"https://www.benzinga.com/23/07/33444916/not-quite-closure-alibaba-exit-leaves-questions-for-sensetime","image":"https://cdn.benzinga.com/files/sensetime.jpg?optimize=medium\u0026amp;dpr=1\u0026amp;auto=webp\u0026amp;height=768\u0026amp;width=1024\u0026amp;fit=crop","image_thumb":"https://cdn.benzinga.com/files/sensetime.jpg?optimize=medium\u0026amp;dpr=1\u0026amp;auto=webp\u0026amp;height=187\u0026amp;width=250\u0026amp;fit=crop","image_large":"https://cdn.benzinga.com/files/sensetime.jpg?optimize=medium\u0026amp;dpr=1\u0026amp;auto=webp\u0026amp;height=1536\u0026amp;width=2048\u0026amp;fit=crop","channels":[{"tid":831968,"name":"Asia","description":"Asia"},{"tid":2,"name":"Markets","description":""},{"tid":6,"name":"Tech","description":""}],"stocks":[{"tid":22280,"name":"AAPL","description":""},{"tid":103794,"name":"BABA","description":"Alibaba"},{"tid":12200,"name":"MSFT","description":"Microsoft"},{"tid":12353,"name":"NVDA","description":"Nvidia"}],"tags":[{"tid":131858,"name":"artificial Workers enjoy the flexibility in managing their schedules and reduced commuting stress while companies get access to a broader talent pool as they can hire people from anywhere in the world.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\r\n\u003cp\u003eBut former PayPal Holdings Inc. executive David Sacks is not a fan of work-from-home (WFH) policies.\u003c/p\u003e","body":"\u003cp\u003eThe remote work trend has experienced an unprecedented surge in recent years. Workers enjoy the flexibility in managing their schedules and reduced commuting stress while companies get access to a broader talent pool as they can hire people from anywhere in the world.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut former PayPal Holdings Inc. executive David Sacks is not a fan of work-from-home (WFH) policies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026ldquo;It\u0026rsquo;s time to admit that remote work doesn\u0026rsquo;t work,\u0026rdquo; he said in a recent tweet. \u0026ldquo;WFH Friday is a four-day work week. Full WFH is a two-day work week.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSacks points out that when people are not in the office, every interaction has to be planned in advance. And that means \u0026ldquo;a lot of information-sharing doesn\u0026rsquo;t happen.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026ldquo;Remote is a great lifestyle, not a way to build a great company,\u0026rdquo; he concluded.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSacks knows a thing or two about building companies. He was the founding chief operating officer of PayPal. Later he built the enterprise social networking platform Yammer, which was acquired by Microsoft Corp. in 2012 for $1.2 billion.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd he\u0026rsquo;s not the only member of the PayPal Mafia \u0026mdash; a group of former PayPal employees and founders who went on to develop other tech companies \u0026mdash; who doesn\u0026rsquo;t like the concept of remote work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCheck out:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eInvesting in real estate just got a whole lot simpler. With as little as $100, average investors are becoming landlords thanks to this \u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/real-estate/22/10/29268850/bezos-backed-startup-lets-you-become-a-landlord-with-100-dollars\"\u003eJeff Bezos-backed startup\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eElon Musk has reportedly bought 6,000 acres of land just outside of Austin.\u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/real-estate/23/05/32537165/elon-musk-is-bullish-on-austin-heres-how-to-invest-in-the-citys-growth-before-he-floods-it-with-new\"\u003e Here\u0026#39;s how to invest in the city\u0026#39;s growth\u003c/a\u003e before he floods it with new tech workers.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eRemote Work Is \u0026lsquo;Morally Wrong\u0026rsquo;\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTesla Inc. CEO Elon Musk is likely the most famous member of the PayPal Mafia. Musk has revolutionized the electric car industry with Tesla and is making significant strides in space exploration with SpaceX.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd he\u0026rsquo;s not sold on the concept of remote work, either.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026ldquo;I\u0026rsquo;m a big believer that people are more productive when they are in person,\u0026rdquo; he said in a recent interview with CNBC.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo Musk, the issue extends beyond productivity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHe noted that workers who make things people consume can\u0026#39;t work remotely. And to assume that these workers have to work on-site while you don\u0026#39;t is \u0026ldquo;morally wrong.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026ldquo;It\u0026#39;s like, really, you\u0026#39;re going to work from home and you\u0026#39;re going to make everyone else who made your car come work in the factory? You\u0026#39;re going to make the people who make your food \u0026hellip; that they can\u0026#39;t work from home?\u0026rdquo; Musk said. \u0026ldquo;The people that come fix your house, they can\u0026#39;t work from home, but you can? Does that seem morally right? That\u0026#39;s messed up.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMusk went so far as to say that \u0026ldquo;the laptop class is living in la la land.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWork-From-Home Stocks Vs. Office REITs\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe rise of remote work has brought about significant shifts in the investment landscape.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor instance, companies providing remote work collaboration tools, cloud-based services and digital communication platforms have experienced significant growth opportunities since the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are now exchange-traded funds (ETFs) that help investors tap into the segment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor example, the Direxion Work From Home ETF (NYSEARCA: WFH) aims to track the Solactive Remote Work Index. It holds 40 stocks, including companies that create popular solutions for enabling remote work such as Microsoft Corp. (NASDAQ: \u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/msft#NASDAQ\"\u003eMSFT\u003c/a\u003e), Alphabet Inc. (NASDAQ: \u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/googl#NASDAQ\"\u003eGOOGL\u003c/a\u003e) and Zoom Video Communications Inc. (NASDAQ: \u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/zm#NASDAQ\"\u003eZM\u003c/a\u003e).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile remote work has presented new opportunities for some companies, it has also had a notable impact on commercial real estate, particularly office buildings. This shift in work dynamics has prompted companies to re-evaluate their office space requirements, leading to shifts in demand.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut if more leaders share Sacks and Musk\u0026rsquo;s view and bring their employees back on-site, office properties could see better days ahead.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInvestors who want to bet on a bounce in this segment can look into real estate investment trusts (REITs) that focus on office buildings, such as Boston Properties Inc. (NYSE: \u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/bxp#NYSE\"\u003eBXP\u003c/a\u003e) and Alexandria Real Estate Equities Inc. (NYSE: \u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/are#NYSE\"\u003eARE\u003c/a\u003e).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you prefer real estate segments with a bit less uncertainty, you might want to look into \u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/alternative-investments/platform/arrived-homes\"\u003esingle-family rentals\u003c/a\u003e. After all, no matter what happens to remote work, people will always need a place to live and a growing number of people are now renting instead of buying. These days, there are even options to \u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/real-estate/22/10/29268850/bezos-backed-startup-lets-you-become-a-landlord-with-100-dollars\"\u003einvest in rental properties with as little as $100\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRead next:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/real-estate/23/07/33236824/this-former-google-engineer-built-a-platform-that-lets-you-buy-shares-of-single-family-rentals-with\"\u003eThis Former Google Engineer Built A Platform That Lets You Buy Shares Of Single-Family Rentals With The Click Of A Button\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/real-estate/23/05/32537165/elon-musk-is-bullish-on-austin-heres-how-to-invest-in-the-citys-growth-before-he-floods-it-with-new\"\u003eElon Musk Is Bullish On Austin. remained active for weeks after the attack came to light, allowing hackers to access government and corporate accounts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWyden and security experts questioned The Wings","teaser":" ","body":"\u003cp\u003eAs the stock market came back up strongly in the first half of 2023, the \u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/calendars/ipos\"\u003emarket for initial public offerings \u003c/a\u003esaw a rebound from an anemic showing in 2022.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eActivity Picks Up Pace. \u003c/strong\u003eThe U.S. IPO market saw 58 offerings so far this year, up 31.8%, and total proceeds jumped 125.5% to $9.8 billion, data from Renaissance Capital showed. This compares to the 2021 full-year tally of 397 IPOs\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e The firm attributed the slackness seen in 2022 to the Ukraine war, a valuation correction in high-multiple stocks, aggressive fed rate hikes, and looming recession risks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTechs Lag:\u003c/strong\u003e Tech IPOs have lagged this year. Across all industries belonging to the tech sector, only 10 companies raised $100 million or more in the first half of the year, FactSet data showed, \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2023/06/29/tech-ipo-drought-reaches-18-months-despite-nasdaq-first-half-rally.html\"\u003eaccording\u003c/a\u003e to CNBC. Cut to the same period in 2021, there were 517 IPOs that raised over $100 million, led by billion-dollar-plus IPOs from \u003cstrong\u003eBumble, Inc. \u003c/strong\u003e(NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/BMBL#NASDAQ\"\u003eBMBL\u003c/a\u003e), \u003cstrong\u003eAffirm Holdings Inc.\u003c/strong\u003e (NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/AFRM#NASDAQ\"\u003eAFRM\u003c/a\u003e), \u003cstrong\u003eSentinelOne, Inc.\u003c/strong\u003e (NYSE:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/S#NYSE\"\u003eS\u003c/a\u003e) and \u003cstrong\u003eUiPath, Inc. \u003c/strong\u003e(NYSE:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/PATH#NYSE\"\u003ePATH\u003c/a\u003e), the report noted.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eSee Also: \u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/money/how-to-invest-in-upcoming-ipos\"\u003eHow To Invest In Upcoming IPOs\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe lackluster trend is in contrast with the buoyancy seen in the tech stocks this year. So far this year, the Nasdaq Composite and the Nasdaq 100 Index are up about 34% and 41%, respectively,\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOutlook:\u003c/strong\u003e Ernst \u0026amp; Young expects the global IPO market to see a resurgence in late 2023 as economic conditions and market sentiment gradually improve with the Federal Reserve's monetary policy hikes potentially ending soon.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut not many agree.\u003cstrong\u003e Lise Buyer,\u003c/strong\u003e founder of IPO consultancy Class V Group, said, \u0026#8220;There will be incremental activity after a period of absolute radio silence but it isn't like companies are racing to get out the door,\u0026#8221; CNBC reported.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eShe reportedly attributed her tempered outlook to the valuation disconnect between 2021 and now, as many stocks haven't recovered from the brutal sell-off seen in 2022.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWall Street Horizon, a corporate events data aggregator, \u003ca href=\"https://www.wallstreethorizon.com/blog/IPO-Market-Showing-Signs-of-Life-Drawing-Second-Half-Optimism-on-Wall-Street\"\u003esaid\u003c/a\u003e in a blog post that a flurry of IPOs may not materialize in the coming weeks, as July and August are typically weak months for IPOs. Given the pickup in secondary market activity, the firm expects a similar trend for the IPO market in the final four months of the year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSome Widely Anticipated IPOs In 2H'23:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eVinFast: \u003c/strong\u003eVietnamese electric vehicle startup \u003cstrong\u003eVinFast Auto Ltd. \u003c/strong\u003ehas implemented a SPAC deal with \u003cstrong\u003eBlack Spade Acquisition Co.\u003c/strong\u003e (NYSE:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/BSAQ#NYSE\"\u003eBSAQ\u003c/a\u003e), which values the former at $27 billion. In connection with the deal, the company has filed with the SEC to offer up to 6.97 million ordinary shares and 14.83 million warrants, along with 14.83 million ordinary shares underlying warrants.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePanera: Panera Brands Inc., \u003c/strong\u003ewhich owns the fast-casual and hospitality brand Panera Bread as well as Einstein Bros. Bagels and Caribou Coffee, in late May announced management and board changes in preparation for its eventual IPO. Incidentally, the proposed IPO will help the company reenter the public market after it was yanked off in 2017 following its acquisition by JAB Holding, the investment arm of the Reimann family.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eStripe: \u003c/strong\u003eAmong the others waiting in the wings\u003ca href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/news/23/03/31170477/stripe-ipo-will-it-happen-in-2023\"\u003e is payment processor Stripe. \u003c/a\u003eCo-founders and brothers\u003cstrong\u003e John Collison\u003c/strong\u003e and \u003cstrong\u003ePatrick Collison \u003c/strong\u003esaid at the start of the year that the company will make a decision to tap the public market within the next year, CNBC \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2023/01/26/stripe-tells-employees-it-will-decide-on-an-ipo-within-the-next-year-.html\"\u003ereported\u003c/a\u003e in January. Stripe said in a press release in March that it has raised more than $6.5 billion at a $50 billion valuation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eInstacart: \u003c/strong\u003eInstacart is a grocery delivery and pick-up service operating in the U.S. and Canada. In May 2022, the online grocer confirmed that it confidentially submitted a draft registration statement on Form S-1. The company reportedly shelved its IPO plans amid the equity market swoon. Now that the market has reversed course, the company could rethink its plans. The company reportedly slashed its valuation by about 40% to $24 billion.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eReddit:\u003c/strong\u003e Reddit, which shot to prominence during the meme stock era, was rumored to be toying with IPO plans in late 2021 at a $15 billion valuation. Fidelity, which led a 2021 funding round, took a stake valued at $28.2 million in the company, TechCrunch reported. The fund's monthly disclosure released in late May showed the investment firm had cut the value of its Reddit equity stake to $16.6 million, down 41.1% from Aug. 2021.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Information reported in February that Reddit could test the IPO waters in the second half of 2023.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDiscord:\u003c/strong\u003e Discord, a chat platform co-founded by \u003cstrong\u003eJason Citron \u003c/strong\u003eand \u003cstrong\u003eStanislav Vishnevskiy,\u003c/strong\u003e could be targeting a $15 billion IPO, Bloomberg reported in March 2022. The platform that is popular with gamers reportedly approached investment bankers in connection with its public debut. Incidentally, Discord rejected a $12 billion proposal from \u003cstrong\u003eMicrosoft Corp\u003c/strong\u003e (NASDAQ:\u003ca class=\"ticker\" href=\"https://www.benzinga.com/stock/MSFT#NASDAQ\"\u003eMSFT\u003c/a\u003e) in 2021.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOthers that could be prepping for listings include \u003cstrong\u003eDatabricks,\u003c/strong\u003e a data and AI company. Earlier this year, the company raised a $1.6 billion Series H financing led by Morgan Stanley, which valued the company at $38 billion. The company's recent acquisition of \u003cstrong\u003eOpenAI \u003c/strong\u003erival \u003cstrong\u003eMosaicML \u003c/strong\u003efor $1.3 billion is seen by market watchers as one step closer to an IPO.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFortnite developer \u003cstrong\u003eEpic Games,\u003c/strong\u003e \u003cstrong\u003eChime\u003c/strong\u003e, a San Francisco-based fintech company, and \u003cstrong\u003eFanatics,\u003c/strong\u003e an online retailer of licensed sportswear, sports collectibles, NFTs, trading cards, and sports merchandise, etc, could also be contemplating a debut in the public market, provided the market momentum continues to be upbeat.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eRead Next: \u003ca
